text:
How do people manage their data/backtesting order?

My data is in zip files. 1 zip per day, containing one archive per market.

At present I use the multiprocessing module with a custom process pool which handles one market/archive per Flumine backtest run. I allow each worker process to run 8 backtests before it respawns.

I'm using a 3950x CPU (16c/32t) with Evo 970 plus nvme.

To prevent concurrent file access (which I am assuming will be slower than serial access), I use a multiprocessing.Lock to only allow one archive to be read at a time.

With this setup, my CPU usage tends to vary from 80-90%. So there should be scope to use it more. I am assuming that it is less than 100% due to the multiprocess lock.

However, after a few minutes, my NVME temp mazes out at 70c, which is at the higher end of its operating range. So I believe it's maxing out.

What do other people here do?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

How do people manage their data/backtesting order?

My data is in zip files. 1 zip per day, containing one archive per market.

At present I use the multiprocessing module with a custom process pool which handles one market/archive per Flumine backtest run. I allow each worker process to run 8 backtests before it respawns.

I'm using a 3950x CPU (16c/32t) with Evo 970 plus nvme.

To prevent concurrent file access (which I am assuming will be slower than serial access), I use a multiprocessing.Lock to only allow one archive to be read at a time.

With this setup, my CPU usage tends to vary from 80-90%. So there should be scope to use it more. I am assuming that it is less than 100% due to the multiprocess lock.

However, after a few minutes, my NVME temp mazes out at 70c, which is at the higher end of its operating range. So I believe it's maxing out.

What do other people here do?

text: Why bother with the zip files? Just treat the markets as the multiprocessing jobs

elements.text: Why bother with the zip files? Just treat the markets as the multiprocessing jobs

text: It’s probably not the lock thats preventing you saturating the CPU though. You’re probably IO bound which would fit with you thinking the hard drive is maxed out

elements.text: It’s probably not the lock thats preventing you saturating the CPU though
You’re probably IO bound which would fit with you thinking the hard drive is maxed out

text: Similar multi-process processing, but I just unzip what I want to cover, and set the thing flying on my Mac Mini M2 .....

elements.text: Similar multi-process processing, but I just unzip what I want to cover, and set the thing flying on my Mac Mini M2 .....

text: Individually gz compressed markets for me

elements.text: Individually gz compressed markets for me

text: I unzip everything first, split my list of files into chunks of size x (for me x=4 is optimal), create a flumine instance for each chunk, and then pass the list of flumine strategies to y workers (y = n_cpus), collect all results at the end, merge, generate a report

elements.text: I unzip everything first, split my list of files into chunks of size x (for me x=4 is optimal), create a flumine instance for each chunk, and then pass the list of flumine strategies to y workers (y = n_cpus), collect all results at the end, merge, generate a report

text: Thanks everyone for sharing. I use zip files as I read somewhere that having lots of small files can cause performance issues on the disk

text: Pretty sure Betfiar only have a smallish number of licenses from TPD. Even if you use BetAngel or BetMover you need to pay for the subscription to the direct TPD feed - Betfair had their licenses way before either of those started provided an interface for the data. TPD actually bought BetMover if my memory is correct.
